abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Cotton (Gossypium barbadense L. and Gossypium hirsutum L.), a major economic crop, suffers severe yield losses due to Verticillium wilt caused by Verticillium dahliae Kleb. Although the lectin receptor‐like protein GbMBL1.1A has been identified as a key activator of hypersensitive cell death in cotton resistance to this pathogen, its downstream defense mechanisms remain unknown. Here, we performed comparative transcriptome analyses between the GbMBL1.1A‐overexpressing (OE) cotton line and its wild‐type (WT) recipient counterpart (WC) under both normal (non‐infected) and V. dahliae infected conditions. A total of 760 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified by comparing GbMBL1.1A‐OE and WT cotton lines under normal condition. Upon pathogen infection across three timepoints, the counts of 1679 (1063 up, 616 down) and 1648 (633 up, 1015 down) DEGs were identified uniquely from GbMBL1.1A‐OE or WT cotton line, respectively, relative to their mock controls. Further analysis of these DEGs revealed three aspects of changes due to GbMBL1.1A overexpression: (1) Pre‐infection priming via selective pattern recognition receptor modulation, mitochondrial cell death activation, and reactive oxygen species antioxidant perturbation under normal condition; (2) Significant enhancement of plant defense against pathogen through the remodeling of immune receptor activity, alteration of signal transduction and regulation, and modulation of secondary metabolic processes, with the most significant alteration occurring in lignin and phenylpropanoid metabolism. (3) Dynamic redox homeostasis regulation through metabolite interconversion enzymes during infection process. Collectively, these findings strengthen the theoretical foundation and provide novel candidate targets for developing improved control strategies to enhance cotton resistance against V. dahliae.

abstract.title: Plain Language Summary
abstract.p: Scientists have found a protein called GbMBL1.1A that helps cotton fight Verticillium wilt, a plant disease threatening cotton production. However, how this protein changes plant immune responses was not clear until now. In this study, researchers compared cotton plants with extra GbMBL1.1A to normal cotton plants under both pathogen infection and no pathogen infection conditions. They found that GbMBL1.1A changes the activity of many genes in both healthy and diseased plants. Before infection, GbMBL1.1A prepares the plant's defense system by adjusting the expression of certain genes. When the fungus attacks, the protein enhances the plant's defense by changing how immune receptors work, altering signaling pathways, and modifying metabolism. It also helps manage the plant's redox balance to combat the diseases. Overall, these findings help us understand how GbMBL1.1A protects cotton from disease and provide new ideas for improving cotton's resistance to Verticillium wilt.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The plant immune system employs conserved pathogen‐ or damage‐associated molecular patterns to initiate pattern‐triggered immunity via the recognition of pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) on plant cell plasma membranes. PRRs, including receptor‐like kinases (RLKs) and receptor‐like proteins (RLPs) that lack a kinase domain, play critical roles in pathogen recognition, triggering hypersensitive response (HR) and immune components as the first layer of plant defense (Ngou et al., 2022; Roudaire et al., 2021). Notably, previous studies indicated that some PRRs and cell death‐associated components are desirable candidates for transgenic engineering to confer resistance across species. Understanding the roles of PRRs and their underlying mechanisms is thus very helpful for providing genetic resources and guidance to improve crop resistance through molecular breeding (Pitsili et al., 2020; Roudaire et al., 2021).

Mannose‐binding lectins (MBLs) are part of the Galanthus nivalis agglutinin (GNA)‐related lectin family, named after the first purified member, GNA (Van Damme et al., 1987). This family is one among 12 families of plant lectins classified based on their sequences and three‐dimensional structures of carbohydrate‐recognition domains (De Coninck & Van Damme, 2021). MBLs play a crucial role in responding to a broad spectrum of microbial pathogens and participate in various aspects of the innate immune response (De Coninck & Van Damme, 2021; Van Holle & Van Damme, 2018). Heterologous expression of a secreted MBL protein known as (Gastrodia elata Blume.) antifungal protein, sourced from the Asiatic orchid G. elata, dramatically enhances the resistance of upland cotton (Gossypium hirsutum L.) against Verticillium dahliae Kleb.infection due to its antifungal activity (Y. Q. Wang et al., 2016). MBLs that localize to the cell membrane are typically categorized into lectin RLKs (LecRLKs) and lectin RLPs (LecRLPs), which can recognize pathogens and initiate immune signaling pathways (De Coninck & Van Damme, 2022). Pi‐d2 is an example of a LecRLK that confers rice blast resistance (Xie et al., 2022). The (Arabidopsis thaliana L.) G‐type receptor kinase lipooligosaccharide‐specific reduced elicitation (LORE) senses medium‐chain 3‐hydroxy fatty acid produced by Pseudomonas and Xanthomonas (Kutschera et al., 2019; Ranf et al., 2015). This sensing induces LORE phosphorylation and the transphosphorylation of the receptor‐like cytoplasmic kinases BS1‐LIKE proteins (PBLs), thereby triggering downstream immune responses (X. M. Luo et al., 2020). Several cell membrane‐localized LecRLPs (MBL homologs), including two from pepper (Capsicum annuum L.) and two from strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa Duch.), have been reported to positively contribute to plant resistance against the bacterial pathogen (Xanthomonas campestris (Pammel) Dowson) and the fruit fungal pathogen (Colletotrichum acutatum J.H. Simmonds. and Botrytis cinerea Pers.), respectively (Guidarelli et al., 2014; Hwang & Hwang, 2011; Kim et al., 2015; Ma et al., 2023; Van Holle & Van Damme, 2018). While the exact molecular mechanisms underlying the roles of LecRLPs in plant defense remain less well‐documented compared to those of LecRLKs, their positive contribution to plant resistance is evident.

The cotton plant (Gossypium), a globally significant economic crop, serves as the primary source of natural fibers and raw materials for oil, feed, food products, and biofuels. Verticillium wilt (VW), caused by Verticillium spp., is a devastating soil‐borne plant vascular disease affecting a wide range of hosts, including herbaceous annuals and woody perennials. Cotton stands out as the most severely impacted crop, with over 50% of planting areas potentially affected, leading to substantial reductions in both yield and fiber quality (Umer et al., 2023; X. S. Li, Yang, et al., 2023). Verticillium dahliae is the predominant pathogen responsible for VW, capable of forming microsclerotia—dormant structures that can survive adverse conditions for over a decade (Shaban et al., 2018). Controlling VW is challenging due to its broad host range, the difficulty in chemically treating soil and vascular systems, and the longevity of its dormant structures (Shaban et al., 2018; Umer et al., 2023). Developing resistant plant varieties presents a relatively effective strategy. However, progress is hindered by the scarcity of VW‐resistant cotton germplasm and the extensive genetic variability of V. dahliae. To address this challenge, elucidating the mechanisms of host resistance and pathogenic virulence could facilitate the generation of transgenic plants or the development of control agents. Employing omics approaches has identified numerous V. dahliae‐responsive genes/proteins involved in salicylic acid (SA)/ethylene (ET)/jasmonic acid (JA)/signaling pathways, xylem synthesis, transcriptional regulation, oxygen homeostasis, growth‐defense balance, and core defense responses reliant on autophagy (W. Gao et al., 2013; Y. B. Li et al., 2016; F. X. Wang et al., 2018, 2011; Yang et al., 2015). Dissection of individual host genes/proteins has unveiled intricate plant immunity mechanisms. These genes/proteins are primarily engaged in initiating Ca2+ signaling (L. F. Sun et al., 2022), maintaining reactive oxygen species (ROS) homeostasis (Y. B. Li et al., 2016), modulating phytohormone signaling (Miao et al., 2019; Shaban et al., 2021; Yang et al., 2015), activating mitogen‐activated protein kinase cascades (X. Q. Gao et al., 2011), responding to chitin‐triggered immune responses (Han et al., 2019), modifying tissue structure (N. N. Liu et al., 2018), producing antifungal substances (Q. Hu et al., 2018; C. Li et al., 2019), and balancing growth with resistance (Chen et al., 2023). Besides, several receptor kinases have been reported to recognize V. dahliae effectors to trigger downstream defense responses. For instance, Ve (LRR receptor protein) and LysM receptor‐like kinase recognize Ave1 effector and chitin, respectively, to initiate defenses (De Jonge et al., 2012; Wan et al., 2012). Recently, the (Nicotiana benthamiana Domin.) receptor NbEIX2 has been reported to recognize an ethylene‐inducing xylanase (EIX)‐like protein VdEIX3 of V. dahliae to induce cell death and defense responses (Yin et al., 2021). Cysteine‐rich RLKs CRK5 and CRK22 may detect Vd‐toxins, thereby regulating the SA‐signaling pathway in planta (J. Zhao et al., 2022). We previously determined that the MBL GbVdI36 (G. barbadense V. dahliae‐induced 36) significantly accumulates in G. barbadense upon V. dahliae challenge (F. X. Wang et al., 2011). Further study designated this protein as GbMBL1.1A through phylogenetic analysis and discovered its interaction with hypersensitive‐induced reaction protein 4 (GbHIR4), which activates root HR‐PCD and enhances cotton resistance against V. dahliae. Overexpression of GbMBL1.1A notably improved cotton resistance against V. dahliae (Yuan et al., 2025). This research underscores the critical role of LecRLPs in plant immunity and their potential utility in molecular breeding to enhance resistance to V. dahliae.

sec.p: As a powerful tool for identifying genes responsive to pathogen infection, transcriptome analyses have been effectively employed to elucidate host immune responses against V. dahliae, the differential reactions between resistant and susceptible cultivars, and the immunological shifts between control plants and those treated with biocontrol microbes (Guo et al., 2022). In this study, we conducted a transcriptome analysis comparing the GbMBL1.1A‐overexpressing (OE) cotton line with its wild‐type (WT) recipient counterpart (WC). Our results indicate that GbMBL1.1A may orchestrate plant immune responses, augment lignin and phenylpropanoid synthesis, and modulate oxidative processes. Consequently, GbMBL1.1A activates defense perception, ROS signaling, immune regulation, and structural defenses, thereby significantly alleviating the suppression of immune responses and cell growth caused by V. dahliae infection. This research provides insights into the multi‐layered modulation of plant immunity induced by GbMBL1.1A overexpression, advancing our understanding of resistance mechanisms triggered by LecRLP‐mediated signaling and offering valuable molecular insights for developing more efficient strategies to enhance cotton resistance against V. dahliae.

sec.title: Plant growth conditions and pathogen inoculation
sec.p: Seeds of upland cotton (G. hirsutum cv. WC and its genetically modified counterpart GbMBL1.1A‐OE) were surface‐sterilized in 70% (v/v) ethanol, rinsed extensively in sterile water, and sown in pots containing vermiculite or grown hydroponically under a 16‐h light/8‐h dark photoperiod at 28°C with 28‐W fluorescent lamps. The GbMBL1.1A overexpression construct and OE‐57 line have been described previously (Yuan et al., 2025). The WT strain V592 (X. Q. Gao et al., 2011) and its eGFP‐tagged derivative of V. dahliae were used in this study. Spores of V. dahliae isolates were cultured in liquid Czapek's medium with shaking at 150 rpm at 28°C for 3–5 days. Conidia suspension (1 × 106 conidia mL−1) was used to inoculate roots of 14‐day‐old cotton seedlings grown under hydroponic conditions by dipping as previously described (F. X. Wang et al., 2011). Samples were then collected at 12, 24, and 48 h post inoculation (hpi) for RNA‐sequencing (RNA‐seq) (n = 45, three biological repeats) and quantitative real‐time polymerase chain reaction (qRT‐PCR) (n = 15, three biological repeats, three technical repeats for each biological repeat) experiments, frozen in liquid nitrogen immediately, and stored at −80°C. For visualizing fungal infection and colonization, the roots of 14‐day‐old hydroponically grown cotton seedlings (n = 12, three biological replicates) from the WT and OE cotton seedlings cultivated under hydroponic conditions were subjected to inoculation by dipping conidia suspensions of eGFP‐tagged V592 strains, and the root‐stem junctions of the infected cotton plants were sampled for microscopic observation and biomass detection at indicated time.

sec.title: Quantification of disease severity
sec.p: Five grades were set for disease severity according to the proportion of wilt leaves within individual plants, including 0 (0%), 1 (<25%), 2 (25%–50%), 3 (50%–75%), and 4 (75%–100%). The percentage distribution of plants among various grades in both the WT and the OE cotton lines was determined at 21 days post inoculation (dpi) following either a control mock inoculation or infection with the V592‐GFP strain, as reported by Zhou et al. (2017).

sec.title: DNA/RNA isolation and cDNA synthesis
sec.p: At 21 dpi, 2 cm long segments were excised from the root‐stem junction of the infected cotton plants for genomic DNA extraction utilizing a Plant DNA Rapid Extraction Kit (Biomed). For the RNA‐seq experiment, roots from mock inoculated (pooled by equal samples from different time points) or inoculated WT and OE seedlings were sampled at 12, 24, and 48 hpi. Total RNA was isolated using a Hi‐Pure Plant RNA Plus Kit (Tsingke) following the manufacturer's protocol. cDNA was synthesized using the isolated total RNA via reverse transcription with EasyScript One‐Step gDNA Removal and cDNA Synthesis SuperMix (Transgen).

sec.title: qRT‐PCR quantification
sec.p: The SYBR Green Real‐Time PCR Master Mix (Toyobo) was used for qRT‐PCR experiments on a CFX96 machine (Bio‐Rad). The cotton GhHIS gene served as an internal control for data normalization to quantify the expression of the differentially expressed genes (DEGs). Fungal biomass in infected cotton roots was quantified using the Verticillium elongation factor 1‐α (EF‐1α) gene as a marker. Concurrently, the cotton 18S rRNA gene was utilized as an endogenous control to normalize the data (Tian et al., 2023). The 2–∆∆Ct method was employed for the relative quantification. All reactions were performed in triplicate, and primer sequences are provided in Table S1.

sec.title: Sequence analyses
sec.p: Twenty‐four cDNA libraries were constructed using three biological replicates for each sample from the isolated total RNA. Transcriptome sequencing was performed on the Illumina HiSeq 4000 platform (Majorbio). After adapter removal and quality trimming, clean reads were obtained by processing raw reads using SeqPrep (https://github.com/jstjohn/SeqPrep) and Sickle (https://github.com/najoshi/sickle). These clean reads were then aligned to the cotton reference genome (http://cotton.zju.edu.cn/index.html, TM‐1_v2.1, Y. Hu et al., 2019) using TopHat v2.0.12. The RSEM software was utilized to compute gene expression levels as described previously (Li & Dewey, 2011). A threshold of |log2 fold change (Infected/Mock) | ≥ 1 and false discovery rate (FDR) ≤ 0.05 was set to screen the DEGs using EdgeR (Robinson et al., 2010).

sec.title: Gene ontology (GO) annotation and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) analyses
sec.p: For the functional classification, the identified DEGs were analyzed by GO annotation using Goatools (https://github.com/tanghaibao/Goatools) based on the cotton ZJU database mentioned above. This analysis encompassed three ontological categories: biological processes (BP), cellular components (CC), and molecular functions (MF). Metabolic pathway enrichment was conducted using KOBAS (http://kobas.cbi.pku.edu.cn/home) and Mapman, following the method described by Usadel et al. (2009). To gain additional insights, we also used SEA tool (http://bioinfo.cau.edu.cn/agriGO/) (Du et al., 2010) for GO enrichment (BP, CC, and MF). These analyses were performed using Arabidopsis homologs of the identified cotton DEGs, based on a background database list from the Arabidopsis TAIR 9. Significant terms were selected to generate graphical results, simplifying and outlining the data. Meanwhile, the KEGG database was used for pathway identification (http://www.genome.jp/kegg) (Kanehisa et al., 2012).

sec.title: PPI network construction and protein classification
sec.p: In this study, we assessed and integrated protein‐protein interactions (PPIs) of the proteins encoded by DEGs using the STRING database (https://string‐db.org/) (Szklarczyk et al., 2015). Due to limited cotton‐specific PPI data, interactions were inferred from Arabidopsis orthologs in STRING. The identified interactions include both direct (physical) and indirect (functional) associations, with a threshold for the pooled score set at 0.4. The DEGs of significant interest were classified utilizing the PANTHER classification system, in conjunction with resources from the NCBI database and the Swiss‐Prot protein database.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: Microsoft Excel (2010 edition) was employed to compute the mean and standard deviation for statistical significance analyses. A two‐tailed Student's t‐test was employed to ascertain the p value (either 0.05 or 0.01). Three independent experiments were conducted, with average or representative results used for data presentation.

sec.title: Enhanced resistance by GbMBL1.1A overexpression under hydroponic cultivation conditions
sec.p: We previously demonstrated that GbMBL1.1A functions as a lectin receptor and interacts with HIR4 to initiate immunity in cotton defense against V. dahliae (Yuan et al., 2025). To elucidate the downstream immune responses mediated by this lectin receptor, we conducted comparative transcriptome analyses to discern the differential transcriptional reprogramming elicited by overexpression of GbMBL1.1A under normal growth or V. dahliae infected conditions. To facilitate RNA‐seq analysis of roots, we utilized a hydroponic culture system and initially compared the differential response to V. dahliae infection between the WT and GbMBL1.1A‐OE plants under these hydroponic conditions. As shown in Figure 1a, the WT cotton plants exhibited characteristic wilt disease symptoms, encompassing chlorosis of leaves, stunted growth, and severe wilting at 21 dpi with V592‐GFP strain of V. dahliae. In contrast, the initial onset of yellowing was observed in a limited subset of GbMBL1.1A‐OE plants, indicating a delayed or reduced susceptibility compared to their WT counterparts. Quantitative data showed that approximately 60% of WT plants exhibited disease grades 2–4, whereas <25% of OE plants displayed comparable severity (Figure 1b). Consistently, we observed a higher density of V592‐GFP mycelia in WT plants compared with GbMBL1.1A‐OE cotton seedlings (Figure 1c). qPCR quantification of fungal biomass at the root‐stem junctions of infected cotton revealed that the V592‐GFP biomass inside the WT cotton plants was significantly higher than that of the GbMBL1.1A‐OE cotton seedlings (Figure 1d). These results indicated that overexpression of GbMBL1.1A significantly contributed to the resistance of cotton against V. dahliae under our cultivation conditions. The RNA‐seq experiments conducted under this system revealed the transcriptome changes corresponding to the differential resistance between the WT and GbMBL1.1A‐OE cotton seedlings during the early infection stage.

sec.title: The transcriptome changes in the GbMBL1.1A‐OE cotton roots under normal and V. dahliae infected conditions
sec.p: Using the hydroponic cultivation system, both the WT and GbMBL1.1A‐OE transgenic cotton roots were cultivated. These plants were mock inoculated and inoculated with V. dahliae strain V592, and samples were collected for RNA‐seq experiments to monitor transcriptome alterations under both normal (mock, water treatment without pathogen challenge) and V. dahliae infected conditions at 12, 24, and 48 hpi. Given that we observed MBL1.1A exhibits peak expression at 6–9 hpi and maintained a relatively high level at 12 hpi in response to V. dahliae infection (Yuan et al., 2025), we selected 12 hpi as our initial sampling point. This strategic choice aims to capture the active downstream response phase, leveraging the sustained expression of MBL1.1A and the clear transcriptional activation of immune components. Using an equal mixture of mock‐inoculated samples from these three timepoints as mock controls for both cotton lines, we then established selection criteria that included an FDR ≤ 0.05 and a |log2 fold change| ≥ 1 to identify DEGs. DEGs were identified by comparing transcriptional abundance between mock‐inoculated WT and GbMBL1.1A‐OE controls. Meanwhile, DEGs were also identified in the infected samples at 12, 24, and 48 hpi relative to their respective mock controls. The flowchart depicting the sample collection and analytical processes of the RNA‐seq experiment is provided in Figure S1a. The identified genes were categorized into up‐regulated, down‐regulated, and “up and down” genes (referring to a minority of DEGs that exhibited inconsistent patterns of upregulation and downregulation across different timepoints in the same cotton line). Upon V. dahliae infection, a total of 3833 genes (1908 up, 1793 down, and 132 up and down) were identified from the WT, and a total of 3902 genes (2225 up, 1254 down, and 423 up and down) from the GbMBL1.1A‐OE line at all three points collectively, indicating substantial transcriptome remodeling under pathogen infection. The most substantial number of DEGs was observed at 12 hpi compared to the other two time points. During this early stage, the WT exhibited a higher proportion of downregulated DEGs, while the OE plants demonstrated a predominance of upregulated DEGs. In contrast, a total of 760 DEGs (235 up, 525 down) distinguished OE from WT plants under normal conditions (Figure 2b; Table S2a). Through comparing the expression profiles of V. dahliae responsive genes between OE and WT plants, time‐course DEGs from all three timepoints were clustered into four categories based on their temporal response profiles and magnitude of expression changes: w−/o+ (uniquely identified from OE compared to WT), w+/o− (uniquely identified from WT compared to OE), w+/o+ D (exhibiting divergent responses to V. dahliae at different time points or with expression changes exceeding a twofold difference), and w+/o+ S (exhibiting similar responses to V. dahliae at the same time points and with magnitude differences less than twofold) (Figure S1; Table S2b‐e). The distribution of these categories among the three types of DEGs (up, down, and up‐ and down) was also examined. As shown in Figure 2b, the counts of upregulated DEGs were 1063, 633, 481, and 529 for w−/o+, w+/o−, w+/o+ D, and w+/o+ S, respectively. For downregulated DEGs, the counts were 616, 1015, 178, and 320, respectively. Regarding the DEGs that were both up‐ and down‐regulated at different timepoints in the same line, the counts were 42, 4, 668, and 25, respectively. Overall, overexpression of GbMBL1.1A resulted in mild changes in the cotton root transcriptome under normal conditions, whereas these effects were more pronounced upon pathogen infection, especially in the early infection stage.

sec.title: Verification of the transcriptome data
sec.p: To validate RNA‐seq results, we randomly selected 5 up‐ and 5 down‐regulated DEGs identified from the WT and OE cotton lines to measure their transcriptional levels. By qRT‐PCR quantification, the transcriptional levels of the selected genes in the OE and WT cotton plants under normal and V. dahliae infected conditions were verified. As shown in Figure 3, the transcriptional levels of the selected up‐ (Figure 3a) and down‐regulated DEGs (Figure 3b) showed the similar change trends with those measured by RNA‐seq (Figure 3c), which confirmed the reliability of our RNA‐seq data.

sec.title: GO enrichment and KEGG analyses of DEGs under normal and V. dahliae‐infected condition
sec.p: To further elucidate the functional mechanisms of GbMBL1.1A, we conducted GO enrichment analyses to discern the biological changes associated with DEGs between the WT and OE plants under both normal and pathogen infected conditions (Figure 4a; Table S3). GO terms were first analyzed based on cotton gene annotations. The numbers of enriched GO terms were 130, 10, and 86 (BPs, CCs, and MFs) under normal condition; the most enriched BPs were associated with ROS, response to SA/ET/ROS/nutrient levels, and cell communication, suggesting the overexpression of GbMBL1.1A can alter upstream regulatory networks involving ROS and hormone signaling (Figure 4a; Table S3a). Upon V. dahliae infection, the numbers of enriched GO terms were 130, 15, and 85 (BPs, CCs, and MFs) for w−/o+, mainly including lignin metabolic process, phenylpropanoid catabolic process, aromatic compound catabolic process, respiratory chain complex IV assembly, and organic cyclic compound catabolic process (Figure 4a; Table S3b). The numbers of enriched GO terms were 197, 26, and 110 (BPs, CCs, and MFs) for w+/o− group, mainly involving vesicle budding, cell wall organization, lignin catabolic process, and phenylpropanoid catabolic processes (Figure 4a; Table S3c). The numbers of enriched GO terms were 222, 7, and 138 (BPs, CCs, and MFs) for w+/o+ D group, mainly associated with response to stress, defense response, response to oxidative stress, and isoprenoid biosynthetic process (Figure 4a; Table S3d). The numbers of enriched GO terms were 175, 12, and 122 (BPs, CCs, and MFs) for w+/o+ S group, mainly related to lipid metabolic process, fluid transport, water transport, and strigolactone metabolism (Figure 4a; Table S3e). Further KEGG pathway analyses indicated that the numbers of the enriched KEGG pathways were 23 for mock, 19 for w−/o+, 18 for w+/o−, 31 for w+/o+ D, and 20 for w+/o+ S (p ≤ 0.05; Table S3a–e). For mock and the four groups of DEGs demonstrating varied responses due to GbMBL1.1A overexpression under V. dahliae‐infected condition, significantly enriched pathways are associated with phenylpropanoid biosynthesis, phenylalanine/tyrosine/tryptophan biosynthesis, glycolysis/gluconeogenesis, and alanine/aspartate/glutamate metabolism (Figure 4b). To supplement the relative scarcity of bioinformatic resources for cotton compared to the model plant Arabidopsis, we used Arabidopsis homologs of these DEGs for GO and KEGG enrichment analyses based on Arabidopsis annotation. Searching with these Arabidopsis homologs significantly increased the number of genes mapped to specific GO terms and KEGG pathways that were underrepresented in cotton‐based analyses (Table S3a–e). By integrating significantly enriched GO terms and KEGG pathways identified through both cotton and Arabidopsis datasets, we aimed to identify key factors potentially influenced by GbMBL1.1A overexpression under normal conditions and in response to V. dahliae infection.

sec.title: Mild immune priming by GbMBL1.1A under normal conditions
sec.p: As GbMBL1.1A interacts with an HR‐related protein to trigger cell death in plant immunity against V. dahliae infection, we investigated genes in the significantly enriched GO/KEGG terms related to plant defense responses and oxidative stress (associated with HR and fungal immunity) to visualize the potential changes due to GbMBL1.1A overexpression. The 110 genes, which account for 14.5% of the total obtained DEGs under normal conditions, were enriched in the GO term (defense response; GO: 0006952) and KEGG pathway (plant‐pathogen interaction; ath04626). These genes were classified into nine groups (Figure 5a; Table S4a–c). The majority (56.4%) encoded immune receptors or defense signaling/regulation proteins (Figure 5a), representing upstream components of defense pathways. A heatmap was constructed to investigate the transcriptional expression of these genes (Figure 5b). It was found that these genes were constitutively activated or suppressed, suggesting that the upstream signaling for plant defense was altered by GbMBL1.1A overexpression. Notably, immune hub genes—including HSR4, RD19B, LECRK91, RLP12, PBL17, CNGC2, MLO‐H1, CRK10/25/26, FLS2, IRE1A, and RPS2—showed transcriptional changes. A PPI network was constructed using the STRING database based on proteins encoded by these DEGs (Figure S2). Eight clusters were identified, with the largest cluster comprising 15 members. Interactions between members were primarily supported by co‐expression and text‐mining evidence, and most genes in the cluster exhibited downregulated transcripts. Uniquely, the transcript levels of the genes encoding proteins with experimentally verified interactions, including RPS2/FLS2, CYP20‐3/HSP90‐1, and PRK/RCA, were observed to be down‐regulated. Conversely, the transcripts of RLP12/LECRK91 were found to be upregulated. Besides, a total of 32 genes in the GO term (oxidative stress; GO:0006979) were uniformly downregulated (Figure 5c; Table S4d), reflecting the transcriptional repression of ROS scavenging enzymes, including cationic peroxidase 1 and peroxidase 4/11/12/24/29/61, due to GbMBL1.1A overexpression. Subsequently, we performed qRT‐PCR to verify these findings; the transcriptional levels of four selected defense‐related genes (upregulated or downregulated) were consistent with the RNA‐seq data (Figure 5d). Similarly, downregulation of four key ROS scavenging genes aligned with transcriptomic trends (Figure 5e).

sec.title: Immune reprogramming by GbMBL1.1A upon infection
sec.p: Upon infection with V. dahliae, we observed that transcriptional changes in a subset of genes were uniquely detected in either the GbMBL1.1A‐OE or WT cotton lines (classified as DEG groups as “w−/o+” and “w+/o−”). The distinct responses observed in both OE and WT lines can provide critical insights into the functions and molecular mechanisms of GbMBL1.1A. To investigate further, we focused on the DEGs that were uniquely identified in the GbMBL1.1A‐OE or WT plants, which best reflect their differential responses to the pathogen. Primarily, we studied the number, functional feature, and expression profile of the genes in the GO term (defense response; GO:0006952) (Table S5) and KEGG pathway (plant‐pathogen interaction; ath04626) (Table S5) that are significantly enriched and highly relevant to host immunity. We found that the total number and the expression tendency of the investigated genes varied significantly between the two cotton lines. The total number of DEGs was higher in OE compared to WT plants, with a significant proportion being upregulated (Figure 6a). By classification, we found that the composition and numbers of DEGs in w+/o− and w−/o+ were different (Figure 6a; Table S5a,d). GbMBL1.1A overexpression dramatically affected the transcriptional expression of genes encoding proteins associated with pathogen perception (immune receptors), defense transduction and regulation, energy/lipid/protein metabolisms, secondary metabolism, and transcription regulation. Through further investigation of the transcriptional expression of genes in defense transduction/regulation group, we found that 29 out of 44 genes were significantly activated in the OE plants upon V. dahliae infection. Many of these upregulated genes were the immunity hub genes, including calcium signaling‐related genes (3 calmodulin‐like (CML) genes, 2 calcium‐binding genes, and 2 calreticulin genes), several HR cell death related genes (three NHL genes and one RBOHB gene), and 2 MKS1 genes (Figure 6b). Comparatively, the majority of calcium‐binding genes (4) and all of the NHL genes (3) were down‐regulated, and no calreticulin genes were identified in the WT plants (Figure 6c). The results indicated that the overexpression of GbMBL1.1A remodeled the cotton immune responses against V. dahliae, as demonstrated by the KEGG pathway enrichment analysis using DEGs in the w−/o+ and w+/o− comparisons (Figure S3). We also performed PPI analysis based on STRING database to construct the PPI network using the encoded proteins from the upregulated DEGs related to plant immunity in the WT and OE cotton plants. Proteins encoded by the DEGs associated with plant immunity from the w+/o− and w−/o+ comparisons were grouped together to form the largest protein interaction networks. As shown in Figure S4, the notable alteration in composition of elements within the PPI network suggested that plant immunity underwent a significant reconfiguration as a consequence of GbMBL1.1A overexpression. Next, we performed qRT‐PCR to verify these findings; the transcriptional expression of eight selected key genes related to plant defense was found to be upregulated or downregulated in the WT or OE plants, consistent with the RNA‐seq data (Figure 6d).

sec.title: OE of GbMBL1.1A activates lignin and phenylpropanoid metabolic processes
sec.p: Upon pathogen infection, the DEGs specially identified from the WT and OE plants were also enriched in GO terms (lignin metabolic processes; GO:0046274; phenylpropanoid metabolic processes; GO:0046271) (Table S6) and KEGG pathways (phenylpropanoid metabolic processes; map/ath00940; Figure S5; Table S6). To further understand the detailed changes, we investigated the number, functional features, and expression profile of the genes in the enriched GO terms and KEGG pathway. As shown in Figure 7a, the transcriptional expression of 33 genes associated with phenylpropanoid and lignin metabolism was uniquely upregulated in the OE plants, mainly including those encoding 16 LACs, six peroxidases, one cytochrome P450 protein, and four mannitol dehydrogenases (MTDs). In contrast, the majority of genes encoding the proteins involved in phenylpropanoid and lignin metabolism were down‐regulated in the WT plants, including 10 LACs, eight peroxidases, and two β‐glucosidase BoGH3B (Figure 7b). qRT‐PCR validation of eight lignin/phenylpropanoid biosynthesis genes confirmed consistent trends: upregulation in GbMBL1.1A‐OE and downregulation in WT plants (Figure 7c,d). Next, the encoded proteins derived from the DEGs that were uniquely up‐ or downregulated in the WT (w+/o−) and OE (w−/o+) plants were analyzed via the STRING database to construct interaction networks (Figure 7e). It was observed that a significant number of hub proteins within the generated protein interaction network were homologs of laccases and peroxidases. Notably, the transcriptional profiles of genes encoding these hub proteins exhibited contrasting trends between the WT and OE cotton plants under V. dahliae infection. These results indicated that lignin and phenylpropanoid metabolism were more strongly activated in OE plants than in WT plants during V. dahliae infection.

sec.title: GbMBL1.1A‐OE influenced oxidation‐reduction process
sec.p: As we found the transcriptional expression of genes encoding dehydrogenases, oxidases (laccase), and peroxidase were significantly changed due to GbMBL1.1A overexpression upon V. dahliae infection, we hypothesized that GbMBL1.1A‐OE can influence redox status, and thus we investigated the transcriptional changes of the genes in the GO term (oxidation‐reduction process; GO:0055114) enriched from DEGs identified as “w+/o−” and “w−/o+” using gene accessions of cotton or their Arabidopsis homologs (Table S7a,b). As shown in Figure 8a, a total of 163 (69 up; 94 down) and 186 (118 up; 68 down) genes were identified in GO: 0055114 enriched from DEGs uniquely identified from the WT or OE cotton plants, respectively. By classification, we found that >80% of the DEGs were genes encoding metabolite interconversion enzymes in the two cotton lines (Table S7), indicating redox status is tightly linked to host metabolism. Gene names, along with the count of their homologs (≥3), and the respective numbers of up‐ and downregulated DEGs encoding these interconversion enzymes in the WT and OE cotton lines, were depicted in Figure 8b. It was found that the genes exhibiting distinct transcriptional responses to V. dahliae primarily encode proteins such as laccase (17), MTD (4), 3,9‐dihydroxypterocarpan 6A‐monooxygenase (4), and nitrate reductase (NR) (3) in the OE plants, and sorbitol dehydrogenase (SDH) (3) in the WT plants. To investigate the interactions among genes encoding enzymes involved in metabolite interconversion during oxidative‐reduction processes, proteins encoded by the DEGs uniquely identified from the OE (w−/o+) and WT (w+/o−) plants were uploaded to the STRING website for interaction analysis. A total of 63 upregulated (OE), 23 upregulated (WT), 27 downregulated (OE), and 38 downregulated (WT) proteins were clustered into 4, 8, 6, and 10 groups, respectively (Figure 8; Figure S6). The largest group comprised 56 out of 63 proteins in the PPI network derived from upregulated genes in the OE plants (Figure 8c), contrasting with nine proteins in WT (Figure 8d). Furthermore, the PPI networks from downregulated genes in the OE and WT plants also exhibited marked differences (Figure S6a,b). Interestingly, CYP84A1, PER64, and LAC17 were clustered together in the protein interaction network of both cotton lines; however, genes encoding these proteins exhibited opposite trends in response to V. dahliae infection. These results suggested that the alterations in the redox state within the WT were distinct and less pronounced compared to those observed in the OE plants.

sec.title: Transcriptome dynamics changes reveal GbMBL1.1A‐mediated immune modulation
sec.p: Comparative transcriptome analysis between OE and WT plants is widely used to characterize immune‐related genes in crops such as cotton (Chen et al., 2023; Guo et al., 2022). Here, we applied this strategy to analyze WT and GbMBL1.1A‐OE cotton seedlings, aiming to elucidate GbMBL1.1A‐mediated immune signaling and downstream responses at the whole‐transcriptome level. The results reveal transcriptional dynamics governed by a lectin receptor in the host responses to V. dahliae infection. In the absence of infection, 760 DEGs were detected between WT and OE lines, indicating mild transcriptome changes due to GbMBL1.1A overexpression and suggesting moderate baseline reprogramming (Table S2a). Upon V. dahliae infection, both genotypes exhibited dynamic transcriptomic responses, with peaking at 12 hpi (Figure 2a). Notably, OE plants displayed stronger transcriptional activation than WT, showing a 2.9‐fold upregulation bias at 12 hpi (1710 up vs. 583 down), compared to the balanced distribution in WT (1071 up vs. 841 down; Figure 2a). This striking disparity highlights a positive regulatory role of this gene in defense. Integrative GO and KEGG enrichment analyses using cotton and Arabidopsis orthologs enhanced data interpretation, leveraging the well‐annotated Arabidopsis genome for functional insights.

sec.title: Constitutive immune priming under normal conditions
sec.p: Comparative transcriptome analysis under no pathogen infection revealed immune hub genes governing pathogen perception, HR cell death, and calcium signaling showed altered expression (Figure 5a,b). Eight genes encoding RLPs and RLKs—including RLP12 (3), NB‐LRR (3), cysteine‐rich RLP kinase (1), and L‐type lectin‐domain containing receptor kinase IX.1 (1)—showed upregulation, contrasting with downregulation of sixteen genes including NB‐LRR (8), cysteine‐rich RLP kinase (4), FLS2 (2), and RPS2 (2) (Figure 5b; Table S4a–c). Given Arabidopsis possesses ∼600 RLKs and over 140 LRR‐RLPs, this selective regulation implies GbMBL1.1A uniquely tunes receptor abundance to modulate immune surveillance. Opposing regulation of RPS2/FLS2 and RLP12/LECRK91 implies antagonistic pathway control, where GbMBL1.1A activates one module while suppressing another. HSR4, a mitochondrial outer membrane (OMM) protein facilitating homo‐multimeric complex formation and SA signaling amplification (B. T. Zhang et al., 2014), was upregulated (Figure 5b), linking GbMBL1.1A to OMM disruption and HR‐PCD. Concurrent suppression of 15 peroxidase genes encoding peroxidase 11/12/24/29/61 and cationic peroxidase 1 homologues disrupted ROS homeostasis (Figure 5c; Table S4d), aligning with GbMBL1.1A‐induced HR‐PCD where H2O2 acts as both a cytotoxic agent and a defense signal. Downregulation of ERFs indicates that GbMBL1.1A prioritizes SA‐mediated defense over ethylene responses under no pathogen infection condition. Collectively, these data demonstrate three synergistic mechanisms: selective PRR modulation, mitochondrial cell death activation, and ROS antioxidant perturbation.

sec.title: GbMBL1.1A‐mediated immune activation in cotton against V. dahliae
sec.p: Upon V. dahliae infection, transcriptomic profiling revealed genotype‐specific immune responses between WT and GbMBL1.1A‐OE plants (Figure 6b,c). OE plants exhibited enhanced activation of defense receptor signaling, including upregulation of NHL10 and NHL13 (key regulators of ROS production and JA/SA signaling), compared to their downregulation in WT (C. Liu et al., 2020). This divergence underscores the role of GbMBL1.1A in amplifying pathogen‐specific immune outputs. Calcium signaling further distinguished OE plants, with upregulated expression of CML, calcium‐binding, and calreticulin (CRT) genes. CRTs maintain Ca2⁺ homeostasis in endoplasmic reticulum and modulate defense protein folding (Qiu et al., 2012), whereas CMLs act as Ca2⁺ sensors to transduce pathogen‐induced signals (Zeng et al., 2023). Altered calcium fluxes in OE plants imply that GbMBL1.1A primes upstream defense signaling cascades. Furthermore, two DTX18 genes, encoding hydroxamic acid transporters, were uniquely induced in OE plants. DTX18 mediates extracellular accumulation of antimicrobial coumaroylagmatine (CouAgm), which synergizes with JA signaling via RRTF1 (Dobritzsch et al., 2016; J. B. Li et al., 2021). This highlights the role of GbMBL1.1A in activating phytoalexin‐based defenses. Additional hormone‐related genes, including 10 auxin‐responsive proteins and 13 ethylene‐responsive transcription factors, were upregulated in OE plants, indicating cross‐talk between GbMBL1.1A‐mediated immunity and auxin/ethylene pathways. Collectively, these data demonstrate that GbMBL1.1A integrates ROS, calcium, and phytohormone signaling to orchestrate multi‐layered defense activation while promoting extracellular antimicrobial compound accumulation.

sec.title: GbMBL1.1A‐mediated structural reinforcement in cotton against V. dahliae
sec.p: The phenylpropanoid pathway and its lignin biosynthesis branch play critical roles in forming physical barriers against pathogen colonization. In plant immunity against the vascular pathogen V. dahliae, this pathway is tightly regulated by immune components and abiotic stresses, including laccase (Q. Hu et al., 2018; Xiao et al., 2024; Y. Zhang et al., 2019), the ScAPD1‐like gene (AP2/ERF transcription factor family), GhWRKY41 (X. S. Li, Yang, et al., 2023), and phosphate deficiency (X. Y. Luo et al., 2021). Notably, our comparative transcriptomic analysis revealed distinct regulatory patterns between OE and WT cotton plants. All 16 laccase homologs were uniquely upregulated in OE plants, while 10 out of 11 laccase homologs were downregulated in WT plants. Concurrently, peroxidase homologs showed divergent expression: 6/8 were upregulated in OE versus 8/8 in WT (mixed activation). PPI network analysis demonstrated that laccase and peroxidase homologs formed cohesive clusters in both genotypes (Figure 7e), suggesting their coordinated regulation by shared upstream signals. As pivotal lignin polymerases, laccases and peroxidases catalyze monolignols (S/G/H units) oxidation into lignin polymers (C. J. Liu et al., 2011; Q. Zhao et al., 2013). Our findings demonstrate that GbMBL1.1A overexpression robustly activates these genes, thereby promoting lignification. Notably, recent studies identified GhWRKY30, GhWRKY41, GhMYB42, and GhTINY2 as direct activators of GhLAC1 (Xiao et al., 2024). We propose that GbMBL1.1A initiates a signaling cascade to recruit such transcription factors, thereby driving lignin biosynthesis genes and fortifying cell walls against V. dahliae invasion. This mechanism aligns with the role of GbMBL1.1A in preemptive defense priming, where structural reinforcement precedes pathogen contact.

sec.title: GbMBL1.1A‐mediated redox reprogramming in cotton against V. dahliae
sec.p: Comparative analysis of oxidation‐reduction‐related DEGs revealed distinct metabolic reprogramming between OE and WT cotton plants under V. dahliae stress (Table S7). In OE plants, enhanced oxidative defense mechanisms were observed, characterized by the specific upregulation of all four mannitol dehydrogenase genes, which metabolize pathogen‐secreted mannitol to suppress ROS accumulation while maintaining ROS‐mediated immunity (Meena et al., 2015). Concurrently, four 3,9‐dihydroxypterocarpan 6A‐monooxygenase genes were uniquely induced, driving glyceollin biosynthesis—a pterocarpanoid with broad‐spectrum antimicrobial activity (Lygin et al., 2013; Schopfer et al., 1998). The activation of three feruloyl‐CoA ortho‐hydroxylase 1 homologs further promoted scopoletin integration into lignin polymers, reinforcing cell wall fortification (Carpinella et al., 2005; X. X. Sun et al., 2015). Conversely, WT plants exhibited metabolic tradeoffs, including the downregulation of three SDH genes, which impaired sorbitol oxidation capacity and stress adaptation (Pleyerová et al., 2022), and the suppression of an NR gene critical for nitric oxide‐mediated defense priming (Chamizo‐Ampudia et al., 2017; Floryszak‐Wieczorek et al., 2016). PPI analysis demonstrated that OE‐upregulated oxidative enzymes formed an expanded interactome (Figure 8c,d), positioning GbMBL1.1A as a centralized hub integrating redox metabolism, lignin biosynthesis, and antimicrobial synthesis. This systemic coordination enhances plant immunity through synergistic metabolic and structural defenses, highlighting a novel strategy for crop improvement against vascular pathogens.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In conclusion, this study elucidates the resistance mechanisms associated with the GbMBL1.1A overexpression in cotton. The innate immune system of plants with overexpressed GbMBL1.1A builds multiple layers of plant resistance by activating HR cell death‐inducing processes and modulating ROS status and defense signaling. Consequently, the synthesis of several defense‐related metabolites, such as those promoting oxidative reactions in the phenylpropanoid pathway (which plays a critical role in structural resistance), was significantly altered. GbMBL1.1A and several genes identified as uniquely upregulated or downregulated in GbMBL1.1A‐OE plants represent potential targets for engineering strategies to enhance resistance to V. dahliae. Future studies should focus on elucidating the subtle mechanisms underlying resistance and determining the MF of key DEGs driven by GbMBL1.1A overexpression, using integrative approaches spanning cell biology, genetics, and biochemistry.
